We are given the number of locks n, then a list of n integers (volumes v1, v2, ..., vn), then q queries (each an integer t_j).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The problem: We have a chain of locks.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Water flows from left to right.
children.label: empty

children.text: When we open a pipe at a lock, it adds 1 liter per second.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Any overflow from a lock goes to the next.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text:
The entire system must be filled (each lock to its capacity) within t_j seconds. We note:
- The entire system requires a total of T = v1 + v2 + ... + vn liters.
-
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: However, because of the overflow, the time to fill the system is constrained by the fact that water must flow from left to right. Key observation:
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: The lock i cannot be filled until all the locks to the left of i are filled (because until then, the water that enters the left locks will overflow to the right). Therefore, the time to fill the system is at least the maximum over i of (S_i / i), where S_i = v1 + v2 + ... + v_i. Why? Consider the first i locks.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: The total water that must go into these locks is S_i.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Actually, we can generalize: for the first i locks, the total water that must be in them is S_i.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Since we can have at most i pipes contributing to the first i locks (because a pipe at a lock j>i doesn't help the first i locks until the locks j-1 are full, but by then the first i locks must be full already), the time required is at least S_i / i.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Therefore, the minimum time required to fill the entire system (if we use k pipes) is at least max_i (S_i / i). But note: we can choose which locks to put the pipes arbitrarily.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
However, the problem asks: for a given time t_j, what is the minimum number of pipes needed so that the entire system is filled by time t_j? We note:
- The total water required is T = S_n (the sum of all volumes).
-
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: In t seconds, we can pour at most k * t liters. Therefore, we must have k * t >= T.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: This is a necessary condition. But also, we have the constraint from the chain: the time must be at least max_i (S_i / i).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The water that ends up in the first i locks can come from any pipe at or to the left of i. However, note that water from a pipe at a lock j (j>i) does not contribute to the first i locks until the locks j-1 are full.

children.text: Therefore, the water that ends up in the first i locks must come from the pipes that are at locks 1 to i. Let k_i be the number of pipes we have in the first i locks. Then the amount of water that can be delivered to the first i locks in time t is k_i *

The problem: We have a chain of locks. Water flows from left to right. When we open a pipe at a lock, it adds 1 liter per second. Any overflow from a lock goes to the next. The entire system must be filled (each lock to its capacity) within t_j seconds.

We note:
- The entire system requires a total of T = v1 + v2 + ... + vn liters.
- However, because of the overflow, the time to fill the system is constrained by the fact that water must flow from left to right.

Key observation:
The lock i cannot be filled until all the locks to the left of i are filled (because until then, the water that enters the left locks will overflow to the right). Therefore, the time to fill the system is at least the maximum over i of (S_i / i), where S_i = v1 + v2 + ... + v_i.
